title: How to Cite the CDC Website as a Source in APA Format

steps.title: List the full name of the CDC and the publication date first.
steps.content: List the full name of the CDC and the publication date first. The very first item in your reference list citation should be the full name of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, followed by a period. Then, include the year of publication in parentheses, also followed by a period. For example: [1] X Research source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2017). If you're citing more than one document from the CDC published in the same year, distinguish them by putting a letter after the year. For instance, you might write "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2017a)." and "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2017b)." Use "a" for whichever source comes first alphabetically by title. For each citation, make the first line left-justified and indent each subsequent line 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) afterward. This is called a hanging indentation .

steps.title: Write the title of the source and the URL.
steps.content: Write the title of the source and the URL. After the name of the CDC and the publication date, list the full title of the CDC webpage you're quoting from, followed by a period. Write it in italics and use sentence case capitalization. In sentence case, most words (all except the first word and words that appear after colons or semicolons) aren't capitalized. Finally, include the URL of the page with no period after it. [2] X Research source For example: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2017). Family health and diabetes . [3] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Alphabetize the entry among your other sources.
steps.content: Alphabetize the entry among your other sources. When writing a reference page in APA format, list all the entries in alphabetical order . Sort them according to the first letter of the first word of the entry, excluding “a,” “an,” or “the.” [4] X Research source

steps.title: Reference the CDC by its full name when introducing a quote.
steps.content: Reference the CDC by its full name when introducing a quote. For the first in-text citation, reference the CDC by its full name (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention), followed by its abbreviation. Include "CDC" in parentheses if you're introducing it as a source before the quotation or in brackets if you're referencing it after the quotation. We explain the 2 different ways to write it below. [5] X Research source With introductory text : According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)... Without introductory text : Certain studies have shown that "Over 30 million people have diabetes" (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC]).

steps.title: Write the year of publication for the quoted material in parentheses.
steps.content: Write the year of publication for the quoted material in parentheses. Always include the year of publication for the source you're citing in-text. APA format is often used by scientists and other researchers who value using the most recent, up-to-date research, so including the publication date is vital. For example: [6] X Research source According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), "Over 30 million people have diabetes" (2017). Include the publication year in an in-text citation even after paraphrased material, not just direct quotes. Differentiate CDC articles or documents published in the same year by adding a letter after the year. For example, your in-text citations could read "(CDC, 2017a)" and "(CDC, 2017b)."

steps.title: Write the page or paragraph number after the publication date.
steps.content: Write the page or paragraph number after the publication date. Write "p." followed by the page number (p. 28). In the absence of a page number (in the case of web articles, for instance), write "para." and list the paragraph number afterward (para. 3). If you didn't introduce the CDC in the introductory text, write the date and page or paragraph number in the same parentheses as the source (separated by commas). For example: [7] X Trustworthy Source Purdue Online Writing Lab Trusted resource for writing and citation guidelines Go to source With introductory text : According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), "Over 30 million people have diabetes" (2017, para. 3). Without introductory text : Certain studies have shown that "Over 30 million people have diabetes" (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2017, para. 3).

steps.title: Use the abbreviated name for the CDC in the introduction to the quote.
steps.content: Use the abbreviated name for the CDC in the introduction to the quote. Only write out the full name of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention the first time you mention it. Every time after that, use the shortened “CDC” to refer to the organization. In this case, you only need to include the date of publication in the parenthetical citation and the page or paragraph number where you found the quote. For example: [8] X Research source Studies done by the CDC have shown that "over 30 million people have diabetes" (2017, para. 3).

steps.title: Cite the CDC abbreviation in the in-text citation.
steps.content: Cite the CDC abbreviation in the in-text citation. If you don’t name the CDC as the source in the introduction to the quote, write the abbreviated version in the parenthetical citation. For example: [9] X Research source Studies have shown that "over 30 million people have diabetes" (CDC, 2017, para. 3).

steps.title: Reference List Entry Example 1:
steps.content: Reference List Entry Example 1: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2024, July 15). Clinical overview of measles . https://www.cdc.gov/measles/hcp/clinical-overview/index.html

steps.title: Reference List Entry Example 2:
steps.content: Reference List Entry Example 2: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2023, November 13). High blood lead levels in children consuming recalled cinnamon applesauce pouches . https://www.cdc.gov/lead-prevention/news/outbreak-applesauce-pouches.html

steps.title: First In-Text Citation Example 1:
steps.content: First In-Text Citation Example 1: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), "Up to 9 in 10 susceptible people with close contact to a measles patient will develop measles" (2024).

steps.title: First In-Text Citation Example 2:
steps.content: First In-Text Citation Example 2: Recent reports showed that WanaBana, Schnucks, and Weis brand cinnamon applesauce pouches are causing elevated levels of lead in the blood of children who consume it (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2023, para. 3).

steps.title: Subsequent In-Text Citation Example 1:
steps.content: Subsequent In-Text Citation Example 1: Measles spreads through droplets when people sneeze, cough, or simply breathe around others (CDC, 2024).

steps.title: Subsequent In-Text Citation Example 2:
steps.content: Subsequent In-Text Citation Example 2: According to the CDC, children ages 1-3 are seeing the most impact (2023, para. 5).
